metadata.title: Journal of Cardiothoracic and Vascular Anesthesia Anesthetic Management of Patients Undergoing Aortic Dissection Repair with Suspected Severe Acute Respi-ratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2 Infection

abstract.text: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-22 is still active in Wuhan, China, and is spreading to the rest of the world. Recently, perioperative anesthetic management in patients with suspected or confirmed coronavirus-2 have been reported. However, there is little report on the anesthetic management of patients undergoing aortic dissection repair with suspected severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 infection. During the outbreak, our team has successfully completed four cases of aortic dissection repair in patients with suspected severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 infection. The purpose of this report is to summarize current knowledge and experiences on anesthetic management in this patient population, and to provide clinical practice guidelines on anesthetic management, infection prevention and control in these critically ill patients.

body_text.text: An ongoing epidemic by a novel coronavirus was reported during late 2019 in Wuhan City, China, which has attracted considerable attentions worldwide. 1 Unfortunately, there is no guidelines on the anesthetic management in patients with suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection undergoing long and complicated cardiac surgeries.

In this study, we report four successful cases of aortic dissection repair in patients with suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection, and summarized current knowledge on anesthetic management, infection prevention and control measures in patients undergoing aortic dissection repair with suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection. We aim to help perioperative healthcare providers to adopt safer anesthetic management techniques and utilize more effective infection prevention and control measures in these critical ill patients. Three male patients and one female patient, aged 51-62 years, were admitted to the   hospital several hours after sudden onset chest Table 1 .

ref_spans.text: Three male patients and one female patient, aged 51-62 years, were admitted to the   hospital several hours after sudden onset chest

body_text.text: All medical staff adopted the third level of medical protection measures, including properly wearing hand-washed clothes inside; medical degree mask such as N95;

disposable surgical cap; medical degree goggles; disposable protective clothing outside; disposable latex gloves; and disposable shoe covers outside. General anesthesia was induced for all patients due to the surgical procedure itself and patients' clinical conditions. To prevent cross-infection in the operating room, disposable anesthetic devices in contact with the respiratory tract, including plastic respiratory pipes, video laryngoscope lenses, filters, respiratory balloons, suction tubes, and sputum suction tubes were discarded after single use. Rescue medications was prepared before entering the operating room and brought to the operating room.

All patients were closely monitored with continuous electrocardiography (ECG), noninvasive arterial blood pressure (NIBP), heart rate (HR) and peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO 2 ). Once in the operating room, two patients had high blood pressure, and urapidil was injected for blood pressure control before general anesthesia.

Invasive arterial blood pressure (IBP) was monitored by radial artery puncture and catheterization with local anesthesia under ultrasound guidance. The first layer of gloves was sterilized with a hydrogen peroxide solution, and another layer of gloves was added to prepare anesthesia induction and intubation. High flow high-concentration oxygen (4-5 L min -1 ) was delivered via face mask, anesthesia induction was performed slowly. After the patient became unconscious, high-dose opioids and adequate muscle relaxant were administrated, and the patient was started on low-tidal volume, high-frequency mechanical ventilation. None of the patients coughed during anesthesia induction. Endotracheal intubation was successfully performed with video laryngoscope. After tracheal intubation, the outer layer gloves were removed, and the inner gloves were disinfected with hydrogen peroxide solution again. Then, anesthesiologists wore a disposable surgical gown and sterile gloves to complete the internal jugular vein cannulation, and connect to the pressure measuring device (Figure 1 ). Nasal temperature probe was placed before heparinized. Finally, a clean drape was placed over the patient's head and face and eyes were taped shut to prevent corneal abrasions.

Due to the long duration of the aortic dissection repair, we used medical adhesive tape to strengthen the connection between the goggles and the mask, between the goggles and the protective clothing cap, and between the mouth and nose of the protective clothing. During the operation, we reduced the operating room temperature and humidity, and changed the protective equipment every 3 to 4 hours depending on the degree of wetness in the protective clothing. Anesthesiologists relief were provided during either cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) or hemostasis stage ( Table 2) . Vital signs of all four patients were stable during the whole surgical procedure.
Preoperative, intraoperative and postoperative respiratory related information of patients, including mode of ventilation and outcomes, was provided in Table 3 .

Postoperatively, patients were mechanically ventilated with oxygen via a portable oxygen source, and transported to an isolation ICU room. After the transportation, the protective equipment and other single-use equipment were discarded at the designated location in the quarantined area.

Accumulating evidences of human-to-human transmission of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) 2,6,11 and a substantial number of asymptomatic cases or patients with mild symptoms 2,3,12 undoubtly posed a significant challenge for the anesthetic management and infection control. In particular, aortic dissection repair is a long and complicated operation 14 Considering the complexity and high risk of aortic dissection repair, direct hemodynamic monitoring with arterial and central lines is necessary. However, wearing multiple heavy protective equipment make these procedures difficult to perform. Real time ultrasound guidance should be used to improve the efficiency and safety. The ultrasound probe should be covered with a disposable cover to prevent probe contamination, which may lead to cross infection.

During preoxygenation and intubation, factors such as coughing, vomiting, and desynchrony between spontaneous breathing and assisted breathing may increase the exposure risk of aerosol and oral secretion for the anesthesiologist. Therefore, adequate anesthesia and muscle relaxation must be achieved before any airway manipulations. Small doses of induction drugs and high-frequency assisted ventilation with low tidal volume during anesthesia induction may reduce the incidence of these adverse reactions.

Finally, the long duration of aortic dissection repair and heavy protective equipment will increase the physical burden for the anesthesiologist, and the protective efficacy of wetted protective equipment will decrease significantly. Moderate hypothermia and decrease of humidity in the operating room can make staff more comfortable, reduce sweating, and reduce the risk of infection. Applying anti-fog agents on the goggles in advance can effectively reduce the fogging and water accumulation from breath and sweat evaporation. Long cases increases the risk of perioperative aerosol infections; therefore, we recommend to use medical adhesive tapes to strengthen the connection between the goggles and the mask, between the goggles and the protective clothing cap, and between the mouth and nose of the protective clothing to effectively prevent insufficient seal. Additionally, protective equipment should be replaced frequently in to maintain the best protective function.

In conclusion, we successfully completed four cases of aortic dissection repair with suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection, and we believe that our anesthetic management and infection precaution measures can provide valuable information for similar conditions. CHD = coronary heart disease; BP = blood pressure; SBP = systolic blood pressure; DBP = diastolic blood pressure

FIGREF0.text: coronavirus was identified by the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention and was subsequently named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) by World Health Organization. 4,5 The disease caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection was named coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), with clinical presentations resembling severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and middle east respiratory syndrome (MERS) and manifesting as cough, fever, and dyspnea. 5-9 In particular, accumulating evidences have shown that SARS-CoV-2 exhibits effective human-to-human transmission causing exponential growth of new cases 6,10-12 . Considering SARS-CoV-2's strong transmissibility of and a substantial number of patients who are either asymptomatic or only with mild symptoms 2,3,12 , this brings great challenges to anesthesiologists for anesthetic management, infection prevention and control. Studies have been published for SARS-CoV-2 related infection prevention and control during anesthesia in emergency surgery 13 .

FIGREF1.text: pain. After admission, all patients were diagnosed with Standford Type A aortic dissection by CT scan. In addition, multiple pulmonary inflammatory changes of varying degrees were discovered on chest CT in all 4 patients. None of them had clear complaints of respiratory symptoms. Patient No. 4 had moderate fever (T = 38.6 °C), patient No. 1 had mild fever (T = 37.6 °C), patient No. 2 had a borderline temperature (T = 37.0 °C), and patient No. 3 had no fever. Blood counts showed a reduction in lymphocyte levels and normal or mildly increase in leukocyte levels. Based on patients' presentation and history of contact, the possibility of SARS-CoV-2 infection are highly suspected, as shown in

FIGREF2.text: management procedures and strict infection control measures need to be developed and implemented, which is particularly important during infectious disease outbreaks. In our study, we reported four successful cases of aortic dissection repair in patients with suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection and provided anesthetic management and precaution measures in these patients with suspected coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).SARS-CoV-2 proved to be transmitted through aerosol or fluid from human secretions or discharges, as well as cough, sneeze and surface contact6,11,15 . These modalities of transmission pose high exposure risk for healthcare providers in the operating room, especially anesthesiologists. In addition, COVID-19 patients may present with mild symptoms or nonspecific signs in the early stage of disease and are still infectious12,16 . Therefore, all perioperative healthcare providers need to adopt the third level of medical protection measures, including medical degree eye-protective goggles, medical degree mask, face shield, gloves, disposable protective clothing, and disposable shoe covers outside13 . Training of personnel for correct use of these precautions is important, and incorrect use may cause potential nosocomial infections and exponential spread of SARS-CoV-2.
